mainmatter.p:
Let \mathbb{R} _{ \sigma } be the Scott space of the real numbers under its natural ordering \le. The Scott opens of \mathbb{R} _{ \sigma } are either one of the following:
The empty set \empty.
The entire set \mathbb{R}.
An open interval of the form [ x , + \infty ] for some x \in \mathbb{R}.

frontmatter.title: Scott open subset of a dcpo

mainmatter.p:
Let (D, \sqsubseteq ) be a dcpo. A subset U \subseteq D is called a Scott open if it satisfies the following conditions.
U is upwards-closed.
U is inaccessible by directed joins, which is to say for any directed subset S \subseteq D, if ( { \bigvee }^{ \uparrow } S ) \in U then there is some x \in S such that x \in U.
The definition here follows the definition at the beginning of Section 2.2 of Mike Smyth's handbook chapter on topology.
Let (D, \sqsubseteq ) be a dcpo. The Scott space of D is the topological space (D, \sigma ( D ) ) whose open sets are given by the class \sigma ( D ) of Scott opens of D.
